requirement:
Art. 15: Accuracy, Robustness and Cybersecurity

Clarifications about Robustness [Recital 75]:
Technical robustness is a key requirement for high-risk AI systems. They should be resilient in relation to harmful or otherwise undesirable behaviour that may result from limitations within the systems or the environment in which the systems operate (e.g. errors, faults, inconsistencies, unexpected situations). Therefore, technical and organisational measures should be taken to ensure robustness of high-risk AI systems, for example by designing and developing appropriate technical solutions to prevent or minimize harmful or otherwise undesirable behaviour. Those technical solution may include for instance mechanisms enabling the system to safely interrupt its operation (fail-safe plans) in the presence of certain anomalies or when operation takes place outside certain predetermined boundaries. Failure to protect against these risks could lead to safety impacts or negatively affect the fundamental rights, for example due to erroneous decisions or wrong or biased outputs generated by the AI system
.

Clarifications about Cybersecurity [Recital 76]:
Cybersecurity plays a crucial role in ensuring that AI systems are resilient against attempts to alter their use, behaviour, performance or compromise their security properties by malicious third parties exploiting the system’s vulnerabilities. Cyberattacks against AI systems can leverage AI specific assets, such as training data sets (e.g. data poisoning) or trained models (e.g. adversarial attacks or membership inference), or exploit vulnerabilities in the AI system’s digital assets or the underlying ICT infrastructure. To ensure a level of cybersecurity appropriate to the risks, suitable measures, such as security controls, should therefore be taken by the providers of high-risk AI systems, also taking into account as appropriate the underlying ICT infrastructure.

Trasversal Questions

rows.Compliance checklist: ●     1. The High-risk AI system achieves an appropriate level of accuracy, robustness and cybersecurity, and perform consistently throughout their entire lifecycle.

_children.Guiding Questions: ●15.1.1    Has the system been designed to ensure an appropriate level of accuracy?
○        What are the technical measures in place in order to check for the level of accuracy?
○       Which is the threshold for the appropriate level of accuracy? How did you identify it? Document and Justify.
○       Which are the limitations of your AI system in implementing technical measures for achieving an appropriate level of accuracy?

●15.1.2    Has the system been designed to be technically robust (resilient to faults and failures, inconsistencies and unexpected situations) as defined in Recital 75? If so, which are the protocols that enhance its robustness?
○        Which are the protocols and technical measures that enhance its robustness?
○        To which numerical threshold does the appropriate level of robustness correspond? Justify your decision.

●15.1.3 Is robustness impacted by the capability limitations of the AI system (e.g. data bottlenecks with the platform, computational cost of the operation) and the need for compliance with respect to other requirements? Document your reasoning and if applicable, measure the impact.
●15.1.4    Does the system maintain cybersecurity across its full lifecycle?
○        Which quantitative indicator(s) and procedures did you consider to assess the appropriate level of cybersecurity? Justify your decision.
○        Which threshold(s) on the previously defined indicator(s) indicate an appropriate level of cybersecurity? Justify your decision.
○        Is there an impact of the cybersecurity measures on the other requirements in Section 2? If yes, document.
○      Which limitations does your AI system present with respect to cybersecurity measures and procedures?
●15.1.5 Do you ensure compliance with the main cybersecurity regulation (i.e., NIS2)? How? Present and justify the normative integration.

●15.1.6 Does the design of your AI System allow to control that an appropriate level of accuracy, robustness and cybersecurity is sustained throughout the lifecycle? If yes, document and justify your design choices.
●15.1.7 Which are the technical measures that guarantee that appropriate levels of accuracy, robustness and cybersecurity are sustained? Justify your choice and describe the measures.
●15.1.8 Which are the limitations (e.g.  frequency) of these consistency checks? What is the impact of these limitations on sustaining an appropriate level of accuracy, robustness and cybersecurity?

rows.Compliance checklist: ●     2. The benchmark proposed for testing accuracy and robustness of your high-risk AI system are aligned with the standards recognized by the Commission.

_children.Guiding Questions: ●15.2.1    Have you checked for existing EU-approved benchmarks or metrics for your AI system?
●15.2.2    Are your methodology and technical measures aligned with recognized standards or practices?
●15.2.3    Does your design allow for the update of the metrics if new EU benchmarks are issued?

●15.2.4    If you adopted benchmarks different from the recognized standards (for limitations or any specific unagreement), did you justify how your choice still remains aligned with official standards?
●15.2.5    If there are no recognized benchmarks, how do you justify your own benchmark adoption (comparing with state-of-the-art in the academic literature etc.)?

rows.Compliance checklist: ●     3. The system’s accuracy and the relevant accuracy metrics used to assess it are declared in the instruction for use.

_children.Guiding Questions: ●15.3.1    Have you specified the accuracy levels of the system and documented these in the instructions for use?
●15.3.2    Are the accuracy metrics documented in the instructions for use?
●15.3.3    Is the documentation regarding accuracy levels and accuracy metrics understandable by the deployer?
○      Is the documentation regarding accuracy levels and accuracy metrics understandable by the human overseer (i.e., recruiter)?
[Please refer to Art.13.3(b)(ii))]

rows.Compliance checklist: ●     4. (Part I) Technical and organizational measures are taken to guarantee that the system is as resilient as possible regarding errors, faults, or inconsistencies, whether these originate within the system itself or from the environment it operates, in particular due to their interaction with people and other systems.

_children.Guiding Questions: ●15.4.1    What classes of failure (e.g., software crashes, network outages, hardware faults) has the system been tested against, and how are they detected at runtime?
●15.4.2   How do you define, and who is accountable for the system’s acceptable mean-time-to-failure and mean-time-to-repair targets?
●15.4.3 Which are the events that could trigger within-system and/or external error, faults or inconsistencies in your AI system?

●15.4.4   Which are the organizational and technical measures that make the system resilient to external errors, faults or inconsistencies (e.g., unexpected user inputs, unexpected change of context)? Describe them and Justify your choice.
○      Has the system been tested against external errors, faults or inconsistencies?
○      How are external errors, faults or inconsistencies detected at runtime?
○      For each possible external system error, fault or inconsistency, what is the course of action that you designed after detection?

●15.4.5    Which are the organizational and technical measures that make the system resilient to within-system errors, faults and inconsistencies (e.g., rapid repeated queries, unusual use patterns by authorized persons)? Describe them and Justify your choice.
○      Has the system been tested against within-system errors, faults and inconsistencies?
○      How are within-system errors, faults and inconsistency swiftly detected at runtime?
○      For each possible within-system error, fault or inconsistency, what is the course of action that you designed after detection?
●15.4.6 Did you identify any event that could trigger errors, faults, or inconsistencies due to the interaction of your AI system with other systems? Describe them
○      Has the system been tested against the identified events?
○      How are these events detected at runtime?
○      For each possible event, what is the course of action that you designed?
●15.4.7 Did you identify any event that could trigger errors, faults, or inconsistencies due to errors by third-party systems on which your system depend on?
○      Has the system been tested against the identified events?
○      How are these events detected at runtime?
○      For each possible event, what is the course of action that you designed?

rows.Compliance checklist:
●     4. (Part II) The robustness is achieved through technical redundancy solutions, which may include backup or fail-safe plans.
[Not Legally Binding]

_children.Guiding Questions: ●15.4.8    Have technical redundancy solutions (e.g., fail-safes, backups) been implemented to ensure robust and uninterrupted operation if one component fails?
○     Are redundancy solutions documented for each component of the pipeline? Justify your choice of redundancy solutions and argue why it guarantees the appropriate level of robustness.
●15.4.9    Where do you maintain redundant copies of critical models, data, and services?
○     Who is responsible for the appropriate maintainance of these redundant copies?
●15.4.10    How often are backups performed, and how do you verify backup integrity and restore procedures?
○     Who is responsible for the backup operation and for the verification of backup integrity and restore procedures?
●15.4.11    What capacity-planning forecasts ensure that redundant resources can handle peak load if the primary path fails? Document and justify your expectations.

rows.Compliance checklist: ●     4. (Part III) If the AI system continues to learn after deployment, it shall eliminate or reduce as far as possible the risk of possibly biased outputs influencing input for future operations (feedback loops), and as to ensure that any such feedback loops are duly addressed with appropriate mitigation measures

_children.Guiding Questions: ●15.4.9    Is your system learning after deployment?
●15.4.10    Which inputs are used for learning after deployment (e.g., machine outputs, human feedback, monitoring and decisions)?
●15.4.11    How do you assess the effect that such inputs may have on the quality of data eventually leading to a change in fairness assessments?
●15.4.12    How are input data used by the AI system (i.e., in addition to processing, for instance for post-deployment learning)?
●15.4.13 Can you describe the learning procedure where outputs are used as inputs in future operations?
○    With which timing this operation is performed?
○    How do you ensure that induced bias is detected swiftly as to ensure an appropriate level of robustness?
●15.4.14    If the system continues to learn post-deployment, how do you ensure it prevents or reduces low-quality outputs from feeding future learning?
○     Does your design include mitigation strategies? If yes, justify your choice.
○     How do you assess if a mitigation strategy has been successful or not?
○     What is your designed course of action in case the mitigation strategy fails?
●15.4.15 Which are the technical and organizational safeguards put in place so to guarantee that the new input data is not  poisoned (e.g. due to tampering by authorized or unauthorized personnnel)?

●15.4.16 Which are the technical and organizational safeguards put in place so to guarantee that the model has not been tampered with during the feedback loop procedure (e.g. due to adversarial attacks)?

rows.Compliance checklist: ●     5. The system is protected against unauthorized third parties to alter their use, outputs or performance by exploiting system vulnerabilities. The technical solutions aiming to ensure the cybersecurity shall be appropriate to the relevant circumstances and the risks. Technical solutions to address AI specific vulnerabilities shall include, where appropriate, measures to prevent, detect, respond to, resolve and control for attacks trying to manipulate the training data set (data poisoning), or pre-trained components used in training (model poisoning), input designed to cause the AI model to make a mistakes (adversarial examples or model evasion), confidentiality attacks or model flaws.

_children.Guiding Questions: ●15.5.1    Which internal and external threat actors and attack vectors have you identified?
●15.5.2    How have you classified cybersecurity risks by severity and likelihood, and how often are the risks and severity likelihood of your threat model re-evaluated?
●15.5.3    Which are the technical measures (e.g. anomaly detection on incoming data streams) that you use to spot unusual patterns indicative of poisoning attempts?
●15.5.4    If you incorporate third-party or pre-trained components, how do you check the integrity of such components?
●15.5.5  Have you implemented protocols for security and deception risks rising from the input data in inference time, e.g., adversarial examples and white fonting attacks?
●15.5.6   How are updates to pre-trained models authenticated, versioned, and logged to prevent silent insertion of malicious weights?
●15.5.6    Which adversarial-robustness techniques (i.e., adversarial training, input preprocessing) are integrated to protect the model against adversarial attacks?
●15.5.7    Do you run automated penetration tests targeting AI-specific vulnerabilities?
○     How often do you run them? Justify your decision.
○     Are the test procedures and logs documented?
○     Who is responsible for the penetration tests and their appropriate documentation?
●15.5.8    In case of incident (e.g. data poisoning, model poisoning), are logs and data securely collected to allow an appropriate post-incident analysis?
●15.5.9    Are access controls in place to prevent unauthorized use or modification of the system?
●15.5.10    Are monitoring systems in place to detect tampering or misuse?
●15.5.11    Have you identified and addressed model flaws such as inherent design vulnerabilities?
●15.5.12    Do you have technical and organizational measures put in place to appropriately address Confidentiality attacks (e.g. leakage of training data)? Describe them.
●15.5.13    Is a cybersecurity strategy in place, adapted to the context and risk profile of the system? Describe it and justify your design.
●15.5.14    Which cybersecurity measures are in place to prevent cybersecurity attacks? Describe them and justify their appropriateness.
●15.5.15    Which cybersecurity measures are in place to detect incidents? Describe them and justify their appropriateness.
●15.5.16    Which cybersecurity measures are in place to respond to breaches? Describe them and justify their appropriateness.
●15.5.17   Which cybersecurity measures are in place to resolve threats? Describe them and justify their appropriateness.
●15.5.18    Which cybersecurity measures are in place to control and monitor the system continuously?
●15.5.19    Are cybersecurity risks periodically reassessed (e.g., after updates or retraining)?If yes, how?
[Regarding to cybersecurity aspects, for completeness refer to cybersecurity law (i.e., NIS2).]

If the AI system has been developed by integrating GPAI models, what transparency measures have been adopted, taking into account the specific characteristics of such models? What technical measures and contractual safeguards have been put in place?
